repnme.cdata!:
China - Reform, Institutional Support and
            Preinvestment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial. Several lessons convey
            the following. The strong motivation, as experienced by this
            operation, shows that a small size credit (with subprojects)
            can have a good impact on the recipient government's
            policy reforms, and institutional strengthening, provided
            timing is fully aligned with a political window of
            opportunity for reform. The project involved a flexible
            process approach, which although appropriate given the
            uncertainties of the demand for technical assistance (TA)
            and of a changing environment, it could however, cause
            implementation delays and difficulties in supervision.
            Partly, the four extensions to the closing dates, was
            related to this. To ensure the project is implemented in a
            timely manner, yet respond to the needs of the policy
            makers, alternative ways should be considered. The Bank and
            Government should adopt a more strategic approach to
            analyze, and prioritize government needs, and identify the
            most binding constraints to economic development, and
            continued reform. Second, subproject planning and approval
            approach, should be improved, by more efficiently meeting -
            the Bank and the Ministry of Finance (MOF) teams - on a
            quarterly basis, to discuss priorities, the assisted areas,
            and agree on the lending program. To keep the momentum
            within a TA project, and allow participation of the
            potentially priority agencies and localities, it is ideal if
            MOF and local finance bureaus, consider taking the repayment
            responsibility of the credit/loan, and require repayment
            only from those revenue-earning agencies.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Reform, Institutional Support and
            Preinvestment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project supports China's
            overall economic reform and modernization effort and helps
            to strengthen selected key institutions responsible for
            policy and research, training and implementation. The
            project has two components. The first, for reform and
            institutional development support, comprises approximately
            10-12 discrete subprojects to be executed by selected
            institutions involved in policy and research, training,
            implementation and other activities related to China's
            economic reform program. The second component is for
            preinvestment and project preparation. It is similar in
            design, purpose and scope to two previous Technical
            Cooperation Credits (Credits 1412-CHA and 1664-CHA). It
            consists of a line of credit available to finance
            feasibility studies, preinvestment and other technical
            assistance needed to prepare projects for external,
            specifically Bank/IDA, financing. In certain exceptional
            circumstances, it could also be used to finance technical
            assistance activities related to project implementation,
            including the national components of provincially-based and
            funded investment projects.
